title: Does DfE have any of the following types of design goals?

options.option: No goals
General design-related goals describing what design should be or achieve
Specific, well documented goals
Prioritised goals indicating which are the most important
A roadmap or plan for how to achieve organisational design goals

title: When are design activities included in planning?

options.option: Design is not included in planning schedules
This usually happens before a design is implemented
This is usually included in planning
This is included in planning and prioritised
This is always part of early project planning or to at least understand whats required

title: How well is the design profession staffed?

options.option: No staff with specialised design skills or experience
Some people with design skills or experience but it's not their main job
Dedicated people in design roles, but not enough to do all the work that's needed or external contractors hired occasionally
Enough specialised people and skills to address current work
No money is spent on internal design staff, external contractors or other design resources
Some design work is funded, but there is no dedicated design budget
There is some design budget, but its not enough
There is adequate budget, nearly adequate or even more than enough budget

title: Across DfE, what do people think design is?

options.option: People don't know or they have a toxic or problematic understanding of design
There is an awareness of the concept of design but limited understanding of the benefits
Some people have a good understanding, but many others don't
There is a consistent definition of design and is understood across DfE
The purpose of design is not only consistent across the organisation, but is applied across departments, services and processes
Leadership does not support design in any way
Leaders are aware of design but are indifferent to it or even hostile
Leadership accepts the need for design but there are some skeptical leaders who aren't convinced or don't provide enough or the right support
There is design support at Deputy Director level upwards

title: How does DfE encourage people to develop their design career?

options.option: No formal design roles exist
Few or no design role but some people are self-motivated and prioritise design work in their normal roles
Job profiles and career paths exist but personal growth and development isn't tracked or understood well
Job profiles and career paths for some design roles are well defined and understood throughout DfE
Job profiles and career paths exist for all design roles and are supported by Design and Research Operations teams

title: How does DfE plan to continue to improve the design profession in future?

options.option: No design work is being done
Design work is done haphazardly, there is little to no effort to evaluate or improve how it's done
Some teams are working towards improving their own work but not all teams are doing the same
Plans are in place to repeat and improve design work across DfE in all teams

title: How and when are design methods used in DfE

options.option: No design or research methods are used
A few are used but not consistently
Design methods are used throughout the delivery lifecycle not just at the end
A wide variety of methods are being used well
Design methods are being used outside of traditional digital teams, for example, finance teams, strategy, policy, support teams, operational teams

title: How do non-design people perceive design?

options.option: No design work is done or it's not talked about
Among non-design roles, design is noted but not accepted or supported
Some people in non-design roles are curious and want to be involved but most don't support it
Most non-design roles accept and support design but it varies across DfE
Non-design roles have strong respect for design and work alongside design roles on various activities

title: How is design work kept consistent across teams and projects?

options.option: It isn't: The only common thread is not knowing or caring about it
Inconsistently: there are many inconsistencies across design within and across projects
Consistently: Design process is similar or consistent across teams and projects
Most non-design roles accept and support design but it varies across DfE
Systematically: There are established, successful frameworks across DfE which are shared, maintained and improved by everyone

title: How does design impact the final outcome?

options.option: Not at all, there is no design work being done so there is no impact
Weak: Design does not have a strong impact or positive outcome on design quality due to politics, constraints or lack of experience
Moderate: Teams are trying to produce high quality work and many are successful
Strong: Many or all of the design work produced is of high quality and meets required standards
Very strong: Designs are good, they lead in the industry and in design community standards

title: How are quantitative metrics used to measure design quality?

options.option: No measurable indicators of design quality are defined
At least a few design metrics are collected and discussed
Design metrics are collected regularly and tracked over time
Design metrics are shared throughout DfE
Design metrics are shared with decision makers and policy people
Design metrics influence decisions
